review_blob: Morkt Hvidtol is kind of a cross between a beer and a "malz", the German non-alcoholic brew, or Israels Birah Schorah.  It is very sweet and raisiny, but has a hint of wheat and a hint of cream in the flavour.  A nice dessert beer when something high-octane doesnt suit.

A real winner out of the Carlsberg stable--a welcome taste for a guy who just moved from Belgium to Denmark.  A very well-balanced dubbel, with the right mix of spice, caramel, sweetness and savouriness.  Am trying to think of a comparable Belgian--perhaps an Affligem bruin?
An ok warm-weather pilsner--a bit on the malty side, which I find good.  Best when cold, but totally drinkable.

A malty, clean-drinking pilsener from Republika Srpska in BiH.  In a place where what you drink is far more a statement about the drinker than about the beer, Nektar is far less offensive in taste than in label--as the label pretty much de-marks the Serb-Muslim border.

A strange brew--probably past its sell by date.  A bit of faint sourness and a bit of cidery flavor, some floaters as well.  Not much sweetness, quite watery in terms of body.  I have a JvG glass so felt compelled to try, but dont see this in my future.
Peat and beer just dont go together.  This beer tastes like dirt, pure and simple.  I dont care if the dirt comes from some Scottish island with a name I cant pronounce, it just doesnt work for me.

A true contender for the title of Best Beer In The World--its muscular strength carrying a boatload of resonant fruity, herbal and malty flavors.  Only complaint is that you cant find it in every nightshop or 7-11.

Not much is grand about this offering--its an improvement over the basic inbev-commodity pilsner that is produced under the Diekirch brand, but it is a bit lacking in taste and strength to make it worth an effort to find.  A faint sweetness is really all that distinguishes it, oh yeah, and a ceramic-topped bottle and ceramic mugs.
Best way to describe this is "not bad for ABInbev".  Very little to distinguish it as an Xmas beer, no noticeable spice or uptick in flavor aside from some faint caramel notes.

Im not usually disposed towards dry golden beers of the Belgian variety, but Valeir Divers knocked my socks off...  When I was asked to describe the taste, the first term that came was "aristocratic." It is dry without being weak or unduly bitter, having almost a savoriness to the flavor instead.  This is what Duvel would like to be when it grows up.

An interesting holiday brew from the Grand Duchy, which tastes somewhere between a good solid bock and a Westmalle Dubbel.  Theres a faint bit of dryness and a faint bit of the raisin mentioned by a previous reviewer--all in, an excellent choice if you happen to be in Luxembourg.

When I tried this in a Maes-flagged eatery in Namur, Belgium, I was skeptical.  Everyone was drinking Watneys, yet I hadnt seen Watneys since the brand died in the UK decades ago, nor had I seen it in Belgium.  I tasted it--and it tasted exactly like Grimbergen Brune, which of course comes from the Alken-Maes/S&N; stable.  Now, I love Grimbergen Brune, and think it could pass as a scotch ale, but this does need to be called out.

A very nice beer and a well-executed concept: a blond flavor profile with pilsner strength.  The result--a beer thats as clearly refreshing as it is clearly a break from a pilsner, wheat or other low-octane brews.  A real winner for its strength.

The last of the old-school Minnesota lagers, but with a clean, fresh and none-too-bitter flavor that hearkens back to the days before  fern bars and microbrews.  To be fair, this stuff is better than a lot of pilsner types around the world, and as local lagers are an increasingly endangered species in the US, this stuff is worth drinking just to keep it around.
Possibly the least tasty Belgian lager--a bit of grain in the taste, but little else of note.  Lacking in any personality, soul or taste--was fortunate that it was served cold at the very least!

Trappieter, one of the custom beers brewed at the Proefbrouwerij in Flanders, is a brew that combines the best features of traditional Belgian brews--a bit of yeast bite and citricity with a balanced version of the hoppiness seen in American and British craft brews.  If this brew ever gets off the ground (I sipped it in a beer cafe on Ghents Graslei with the brewer himself), it could have a lot of appeal in the US--where its modest alcohol punch and its hoppy notes could make it a real winner.  Most similar to Hennepin, but with a more complex flavor.

Muller Brau is one of the nicest basic pilseners Ive had in a long while, and vastly more congenial than most of the other basic Swiss brews.  A clean foretaste--more malty than hoppy (I know most RB readers are hop-heads but Ill take malt over hop any day of the week).  One could spend a pleasant evening pounding these back...

This has a clear sherry taste to it--which gives it a real personality distinct from its big sister Augustijn or other tripel-style brews.  Nutty aftertaste balancing a mild but persistent fruitiness.
A quirky but very interesting tripel--great color, a bit of spiciness and fruitiness balanced with a touch of acidity.  Not as strong as most tripels at only 7.5, but an immensely flavorful brew.
UPDATED: JUL 23, 2010
Learning that InBev makes this brew answered my question about why this brew lacks much soul or character, even by pilsner standards.  Shocking that its numero uno in Croatia.

Given that I detested their Delftse Mueselaere Bier and was extremely skeptical, I gingerly took my first sip.  To my surprise--a combination of the light amber sweetness of a Palm with a distinctive, very pleasant but tough to distinguish.  Its hard to describe this--Palm with a surprise is probably the best.  But the deScription doesnt do it justice--if you see this beer (and be sure to try the KUYTE and not the MUESELAERE) GO FOR IT.
A most unusual biere de noel--not the traditional heavily spiced near-quadrupel, but more acidic and yeasty.  Not a bad effort by any means--though I prefer Val-Dieus Brune.

Hertog Jan is probably the most innovative of the Inbev breweries, and Karakter is one of their better efforts--kind of a junior tripel with the kind of amber color, mild sweetness and ethereal spice, but with slightly less alcohol.  Had on tap--it was a solid performer.
A solid effort from the Trappists of Tilburg.  Not as stunning as their Quadrupel, but a fine, spicy tripel that is balanced with a very mild sweetness.  Very good with spicy food.
A bit disappointing for the depth and gravity of this brew.  A nice brew--very mild for its strength--but lacking the unctuousness of the Kasteel Bruin or the cognac-like power of the Bush.

I think this may well be the best blond-style beer around:  Its got great spice, a lot of body and heart, and just the right degree of carbonation.  I tried this in Luxembourg so it may have been the conditions.  Still, a real winner.

As a new resident in Delft, I had high hopes for this brew.  But it lacked an even basic drinkability--it was really hard work and for a low countries brew of such gravity, that came as a surprise.  Exaggerated hop and yeast flavors give this a soapiness that compares to Tide and Persil.  Storage may be the problem, as I got mine at the c1000 supermarket in Delfts Zuidpoort shopping centre.

Quite possibly, the best beer in Ar-Hen-Tina.  Not quite a 90 shilling from Edinburgh, but a nice brew with deep color, a bit of sweetness, very mild carbonation, and an ever so mild hop taste.  Credible stuff.

A really mediocre attempt at a Boddingtons type brew--lacking in flavor, bouquet or "cream".  Also, Bullers prices are horrific for Argentina--though their brew pubs are packed with Argentines willing to pay London/East Coast prices to avoid contamination by the riff raff.
Non-deScript lager--nothing offensive but nothing worth crossing the street for.  No worse than such US beers as Old Style or UK beers like Carling.

I got this in a care package from my brother in Portland, and to be honest, I kind of dreaded opening what I thought would be yet another over-hopped American IPA clone.  But the mildness and roundness of Full Sail really ensnared me--sure there was a little bitterness, but there was also a faint acidity and a hint of maltiness.  It reminds me much more of a Palm or a Vieux Temps (Belgian pale ales) than an over-hopped US microbrew.
Rather bitter and toasty for an Abt--but with deep, well rounded flavors.  Prefer Kasteel and Konigshoeven, but this still a world-class product nonetheless.
Port winish aroma, with a unique taste that bridges classic porter-stout bitterness with a belgian sweetness.  Port wine notes in the finish
Maudites has some harsh flavors--particularly when compared with mellifluous stablemate La Fin Du Monde. Still, a decent effort--good strength, body and yeastiness.

beer_brewer_name: Hair of the Dog Brewing Company
review_blob: Its hard not to respect a barley wine that weighs in at ten percent--but this tastes like a very harsh version of Gold Label...  Too much hop is NOT a good thing.

What a total, disgraceful rip-off.  At best, this tastes like a spiked knockoff of EKU 28--harshly hopped, with the raisins used probably for alcohol fodder than for flavor.  But for 8.99 in an off-license, one expects spectacular.  This one is merely weird.
UPDATED: SEP 8, 2006
Not bad for a microbrewed lager--not overhopped like most US micros, but lacking a bit on the maltiness side of the spectrum.  Still, a refreshing change of pace after a Pilsner Urquell...

A bit disappointing for a beer of its weight--it has much lighter color than most abt-type beers, and, while relatively pleasant, was no match for something like a Kasteel Tripel.  Not bad--wouldnt turn a free one down, but not a true contender.

A truly first-rate offering--very impressive to non Belgian Beer fans in its lovely 750 bottle.

Its a quirky brune--a bit hoppier than usual, but providing ample quantities of caramelized malt behind it.  Not overpowering, but very pleasing with a bit of spice to it as well.

West Virginians are VERY lucky to have this little low-hopped gem in their midst.  Cheat Mountain breaks the often over-hopped microbrew mold with a bold maltiness and light carbonation and only the lightest of hop touches.  Very similar to Belgiums Primus.  Id consider it one of the top 10 lager-type beers I have ever had, "and Ive had them all over the woild" (apologies to Irving Woltz of the Godfather).

Im not a big honey beer fan, but this contender successfully straddles the fence between its honey origins and its Belgian ambitions.  This beer is as subtle as it is strong, and it is very, very strong...  As good as anything Ive tasted from a microbrewery.
beer_name: Atlantic Brother Adams Honey Bragget Ale

review_blob: As befitting the label, this is one of the worlds scariest beers.  The overriding flavor was that of dissolved tobacco smoke, which permeated the whole experience.  To be sure, the beer was inadequately refrigerated, but this was definitely a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
A really respectable Abbey dubbel--well balanced flavors (maltiness, hoppiness, spice).  Commercial stuff to be sure, but meters ahead of rivals Ciney and Leffe
A half-way decent Belgian white, competitive with Hoegaarden and Blue Moon for sure, perhaps a bit more astringent.
A weird combination of "overly sweet" and "overly hoppy"--in a land of great beers, this one can only qualify as strange.

Dark and lovely, with a diverse range of flavors--a little bitter but mostly sweet and sour.  The sweetness in quite complex--kind of like the crust on a creme brulee.  A much more interesting beer than the Tremens.

Kolsch is a light and refreshing style, and Reissdorf is no exception to the rule--though its aftertasts is a bit more hoppy and bitter than fresh.  I prefer Kuppers, which is cleaner and ever so slightly fruitier.  Still, not a bad brew--definitely preferable to most German lagers/pilsners.
